By the time the British Empire could be called that, Britain was a democracy (or thereabouts), and had been religiously plural for some time. At the height of the Empire toward the end of the 19th century the Church in Wales was disestablished in response to the growth of Methodism, and many other sects, Congregationalists, Baptists, Quakers, etc. could all be found in Britain's major cities. The end of religious monopoly largely coincided with the beginning of Empire, so you have it backward.
 
 A more sensible example would be the Reichschurch set up by Hitler, to avoid true Christianity being preached and undermining the Reich. You might also look at the opposition of the Chinese to the Roman Catholic church - it's not so much a matter of freedom as loyalty to an external power. Let's not forget that Catholics are still regarded with some suspicion in US politics, certainly when JFK was elected.
